block.p: David Gibson depicts Benedict XVI as a hard-liner who is trying to change his image by ''carefully accentuating the positive'' while in reality he's clamping down and being as reactionary as you might expect.
But Pope Benedict's writings are incongruous with this picture.

His first encyclical, ''God Is Love,'' turns out to include an exquisite summary of a notion that Benedict has been savoring for years: God's love, Benedict asserts, includes elements of eros, or love as desire, as well as agape, love as beneficence.
So could it be that he is saying something revolutionary, not reactionary, in a document meant to stamp his papacy? I think so, and his actions have followed suit.

The Regensburg, Germany, speech led to a colloquium and a dialogue with Muslim leaders. This isn't a surprise since the pope in his writings has long been a proponent of peace between religions as a way to peace between nations.
European intellectuals have found in him a sounding board for their ideas.
Just days ago, Benedict signed on to a document that makes the teaching of limbo a thing of the past. That doesn't seem to me like the pattern of a man bent on vindicating old dogmas.
